text: - Hi and welcome to our masterclass
for Data Governance on AWS.
I'm Kevin Lewis,

I am in the AWS Professional
Services Organization,
working on data strategy and governance.
And I have been in consulting for about
the last 15 years or so.
Before that, I worked for a large retailer

where I was responsible for my
own data management program.

And in my time in consulting,
I've visited, geez,
probably, well over 100 customers,

either for short conversations
or long-term engagements.

And there are some things
that we've observed

that are very consistent
patterns of things

that cause organizations
to run into trouble
as they're implementing data governance

and really significant
elements of success,
things that work very consistently.

And there's a lot of
things that I wish I knew

when I was starting my own
data governance program
that I had to figure out over time.
And I'd love to share those with you
over the course of these videos.

So let's start with what
is this thing called
data governance?
What is it about?
Now, if you look for definitions,
you're gonna find a lot of things like
decision rights and policy and access
and all of those things.

And the definitions you find
are of course, accurate,
but they may not necessarily be practical.
So for our purposes,
let's talk about what data governance is

in a way that can help us
succeed with implementing it.
And so let's think about it this way.
Let's think about data governance
as making sure your organization's data

is in the right condition
needed to succeed

with business initiatives
and business operations.
And we'll find that in order to get data

in the right condition
for business initiatives,

it takes a partnership
between the business and IT.

So for example, let's say
with an insurance company,
and I want to improve claims adjudication.

Alright, well, we know that
in order to process claims,
information has to be captured adequately
within the claim information.

Now we know that it
requires a lot of knowledge

about the business of what a
claim is and how it's processed

and the kind of information
that's necessary
to effectively adjudicate a claim

and the kinds of data
issues that would slow down
the process of adjudicating a claim.

So because getting that
data in the right condition

is not purely a technical issue,
it's also a business issue,
that's why we need a partnership
between IT and the business,
and we call this data governance.

So that's a more practical
way to think about it.

And so let's talk a little
bit about the people
that are involved in this process.
So we'll hear the term data steward,
so what do we mean by a data steward?

So a data steward is a
person from the business

who has detailed knowledge
of the data that's needed
to support targeted business initiatives.
So if I am in this insurance company

and we are trying to improve
the quality of claims data

in order to improve
adjudication of claims.

Well then I need someone
in that project day to day

to do some specific things
in partnership with IT.

We need to evaluate the
quality of the data.
We need to develop data quality rules
for monitoring the data
and taking action when there are issues.
And we need someone to work with IT

to leverage technologies
in order to accelerate
some of these processes.
So this is the role of the data steward
within the data governance process,

and especially within the
projects that leverage data
for business needs.
So that's the data steward role.
And so you can see why it's so important

that the data steward be
someone from the business.
In fact, DEMA, it's a very popular,

very well-known data
management organization,
they have a phrase that I like,

they say data stewards
are found, not made.

And I like that because
really there are probably

already people in your
organization who are doing this

kind of work, they're just
not officially sanctioned.

They may not have the formal
roles and responsibilities,

but there are already
people in the organization
doing this kind of work.
So one approach to finding data stewards
is to look for the people who are sort of
doing this kind of work already today

and then wrap some
formalization around that role.

So let's talk a little
bit about another role
called the data owner.
So a data owner would be somebody

who more at an executive
level would do things
like make policy around the data.
So they would decide, for example,
who has access to claims data,
who has access to customer data,

they can resolve any issues
about definitions of terms
like what is a customer?
What is revenue?

These are things that
have to be figured out

so they can help to resolve
some of those things.

And so again, this is a role
that comes from the business
and it's more of an executive level role.
So that's the data owner.
So there's a clear relationship

between the data owner
and the data steward

where the data steward is
more day-to-day involvement
in projects,

and the data owner is
more at the policy level.
Now let's talk about the role of IT.

So the role of IT would
be to help navigate

all of the systems that both
produce and consume data,
but they also want to enable data stewards

with the right tools and
technologies and capabilities.

So we'll find that things
like data quality management
and master data management and data access
and all of those things can be enabled
and accelerated by modern technology.
So this is why when we're building
a data governance program,

we wanna make sure that there
is roles for the business,

roles for IT, and that
we're working together.

And again, going back to
the definition of ensuring
that we are, in preparing the data

to support the success
of business initiatives,

we call that at Amazon, we
call that working backwards.

Working backwards from
the business initiative
to decide how to prioritize,
what to do with data governance,
and the underlying technology and so on.

So this group that works
together from the business

and IT needs to ensure that
they are in fact aligned
to those business initiatives.

Now let's talk about
another level of this,

another level of a data
governance program,
in addition to helping succeed
with individual business initiatives
and the use cases within them,
is to look across business initiatives,
to look across the organization.
So for example, reusing data.
So going back to our claims example,

you're gonna find that
within an insurance company,
there are many, many uses for claims data,
not just for claims adjudication

but things like maybe loss
prevention, fraud detection,
things like that.

Understanding the cost
associated with claims
and many other things.

So the data governance
program can help look across
business initiatives
and ensure that when we are preparing data
to be useful for a business initiative,

that it's actually being deployed
in a way that it can scale

and be shared across a wide
variety of business initiatives.
And another way that it can be beneficial
to look across initiatives

is to think about the level
of integration required.

So bringing data in from
a variety of sources

to be used in multiple
business initiatives.
So let's take for example,
a customer experience for a retailer.

So you need to integrate
data about the customer
from across various channels.

You need to integrate data of
transactions and touchpoints
for web interactions and physical stores.

And all of those things
need to be pulled together.
Now that doesn't happen automatically
because all of this data comes from
a variety of different systems.
You have to do certain things to make sure

the data fits together in
order to serve the needs

of something like a customer
experience initiative.

And that requires, again,
business and IT to work together

to make sure that the data
can be linked together,
it's of high quality, it's coherent.
And if you're doing all the hard work

of pulling this data together
from a variety of sources,
why not leverage that for

initiative after
initiative after initiative

so your data resources get
better and better and better
over time.
What we have seen in real life

is that very often a business
initiative will start up
and it will try to thread together data

from a variety of different
sources for their purposes.

And then the next
initiative will come along

and do it again, and then do
it again, and do it again.

So having an effective
data governance program
means that you are putting in place

all the processes and the
procedures and strategies

so that you can do this
just as a natural course
of doing business.
So in our time together,

we're gonna talk about
some more of the details
of how to make this happen.

We'll talk about some very
common strategic issues
and some very subtle ones
that can really get you into trouble.

And we'll do our best
to shine a spotlight on
the difference between the right way
and the wrong way to do things.

We'll talk about the
distribution of responsibilities

within the roles that are
involved in data governance

and how to do that
effectively and lots more.
So we'll talk about underlying technology,

we'll talk about some of
the detailed processes
that are involved.

And importantly, we'll talk
about how to sustain the program
going forward.
So once you do all this work
to get the program started,
how do I keep the program healthy?
How do I keep it going?
How do I make it a part of just the way
the organization does business?
So we'll be talking about that
and thank you for spending time with me.
